issues.description: The problem statement requires a static method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) (see UML and textual description). The reference solution instead provides a static method named receiveDelivery(String, int, int) in SealSaloon.java. This name mismatch between the specification and the solution is a structural inconsistency: tests, examples, and the textual requirements refer to acceptSupplyDelivery, so students (and automated tests) will expect that exact API. The solution having a different method name may confuse students comparing their work to the reference or cause the reference to fail tests that rely on the specified name.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the reference solution match the problem specification by renaming the static method receiveDelivery(...) to acceptSupplyDelivery(...). Alternatively, keep receiveDelivery(...) but add a static wrapper acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity) that delegates to receiveDelivery so the API expected by the problem/tests is provided.

issues.description: The UML fragment in the problem statement lists methods (e.g., calculateTotalPrice and acceptSupplyDelivery) and attributes but does not mark them as static. Later in the textual instructions the problem explicitly states that the stock attribute and the methods acceptSupplyDelivery and calculateTotalPrice must be static. This difference between the UML (which omits the static marking) and the textual requirements can confuse students about whether those members should be static or instance-level.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the UML or the textual description so they are consistent: either update the UML to mark stock, acceptSupplyDelivery, and calculateTotalPrice as static, or revise the textual instructions to match the UML. Prefer updating the UML to indicate static members (e.g., underline or stereotype) so the diagram and text convey the same design.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual description) specifies a static method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) to handle incoming ingredient deliveries. The solution implementation instead provides a static method named receiveDelivery(String, int, int) in SealSaloon. This is a direct naming mismatch for the same conceptual operation (accepting a supply delivery) and can confuse students mapping the requirement to the implementation or tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across artifacts. Rename solution's receiveDelivery(...) to acceptSupplyDelivery(...) (keeping it static and same signature), and update any internal callers accordingly — or alternatively update the problem statement/UML to use receiveDelivery if that name is preferred. Prefer matching the problem statement to avoid confusing students.
